metadata.title: Novel Immunoglobulin Domain Proteins Provide Insights into Evolution and Pathogenesis Mechanisms of SARS-Related Coronaviruses

abstract.text: A novel coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) is the causative agent of an emergent severe respiratory disease 20 in humans that is threatening to result in a global health crisis. By using genomic, sequence, 21 structural and evolutionary analysis, we show that Alpha-and Beta-CoVs possess several novel families 22 of immunoglobulin (Ig) domain proteins, including ORF8 and ORF7a from SARS-related coronaviruses 23 and two protein groups from certain Alpha-CoVs. Among them, ORF8 is distinguished in being rapidly 24 evolving, possessing a unique insert and a hypervariable position among SARS-CoV-2 genomes in its 25 predicted ligand-binding groove. We also uncover many Ig proteins from several metazoan viruses 26 which are distinct in sequence and structure but share an architecture comparable to that of CoV Ig 27 domain proteins. Hence, we propose that deployment of Ig domain proteins is a widely-used strategy by 28 viruses, and SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 is a potential pathogenicity factor which evolves rapidly to counter the 29 immune response and facilitate the transmission between hosts. 30 31

body_text.text: Nidoviruses are an ancient group of lipid-enveloped viruses with non-segmented RNA genomes, which 35 are known to infect oomycetes and animals, including molluscs, arthropods and vertebrates (1). Among 36 them are the coronaviruses (CoVs) which possess the largest known monopartite RNA genomes and are 37 classified into four genera-Alphacoronavirus, Betacoronavirus, Gammacoronavirus, and 38
Deltacoronavirus (2) . Over the past two decades, Beta-CoVs, including the viruses responsible for 39

Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) in 2003 and Middle Eastern Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) in 40 2012, have emerged as significant local land global health concerns with economic consequences (3, 4) . 41 window size and step size. Open reading frames of virus genomes used in this study were extracted 66 from an NCBI Genbank file. 67 68 Protein sequence analysis 69

To collect protein homologs, iterative sequence profile searches were conducted by the programs PSI-70 BLAST (Position-Specific Iterated BLAST)(12) and JACKHMMER (15), which searched against the non-71 redundant (nr) protein database of NCBI with a cut-off e-value of 0.005 serving as the significance 72 threshold. Similarity-based clustering was conducted by BLASTCLUST, a BLAST score-based single-linkage 73 clustering method (ftp://ftp.ncbi.nih.gov/blast/documents/blastclust.html). Multiple sequence 74 alignments were built by the KALIGN (14), MUSCLE(16) and PROMALS3D(17) programs, followed by 75 careful manual adjustments based on the profile-profile alignment, the secondary structure information 76 and the structural alignment. Profile-profile comparison was conducted using the HHpred program (18). 77

The consensus of the alignment was calculated using a custom Perl script. The alignments were colored 78 using an in-house alignment visualization program written in perl and further modified using adobe 79 illustrator. Signal peptides were predicted by the SignalP-5.0 Server (19 P is the fraction of residues of amino acid type i, and M is the number of amino acid types. The Shannon 104 entropy for the ith position in the alignment ranges from 0 (only one residue at that position) to 4.32 (all 105 20 residues equally represented at that position). Analysis of the entropy values which were thus 106 derived was performed using the R language. 107 108

The secondary structural prediction was conducted using the Jnet (Joint Network) program (27). Jnet is a 110 neural network-based predictor which trains neural networks from three different types of profiles: 111 profile PSSM, profile HMM, and residue frequency profile. It generates a consensus secondary structure 112 with an average accuracy of 72% or greater. 113

The Modeller9v1 program (Sali and Blundell, 1993) was utilized for homology modeling of structure of 115 SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 using the SARS-CoV ORF7 (1xak_A) (28) as a template. Since in these low sequence-116 identity cases, sequence alignment is the most important factor affecting the quality of the model 117 (Cozzetto and Tramontano, 2005) , alignments used in this study have been carefully built and cross-118 validated based on the information from HHpred and edited manually using the secondary structure 119 information. We generated five models and selected the one that had better model accuracy p-value 120

and global model quality score as assessed by ModFOLD6 online server (29). Structural analysis and 121 comparison were conducted using the molecular visualization program PyMOL (30). The structural 122 similarity search was performed using the DALI server (31). 123 124

The host-pathogen arms-race has selected for a disparate complement of viral genes involved in 127 pathogenesis. These genes often rapidly diversify through recombination and mutations to keep up with 128 the evolution of host resistance. To identify proteins with potential pathogenic roles in COVID-19, we 129 conducted a comparative genomic analysis of the coronaviruses. Similarity plots show that the bat CoV 130
body_text.section: Comparative genomics unveils fast-evolving regions of SARS-related CoV genomes 126

body_text.text: RaTG13 is the closest relative of SARS-CoV-2 with no evidence for recombination between them ( Figure  131 1 and Figure S1 ). SARS-CoV-2 also shows good similarity to two other bat viruses, CoVZXC21 and 132
body_text.section: Comparative genomics unveils fast-evolving regions of SARS-related CoV genomes 126

body_text.text: CoVZXC45, first in the 5' half of ORF1 and again after nucleotide number 20,000 of the genome. 133
body_text.section: Comparative genomics unveils fast-evolving regions of SARS-related CoV genomes 126

body_text.text: However, the remaining part of ORF1 of SARS-CoV-2 and RatG13 show no specific relationship to these 134 viruses. This suggests a recombination event between the common ancestor of SARS-CoV-2 and RaTG13, 135 and probably another member of the SARS-related clade close to CoVZXC21 and CoVZXC45. In addition 136 to this major recombination event, we identified several smaller regions which might have undergone 137 recombinational diversification during the emergence of the SARS-CoV-2 genome ( Figure S1 ). Notably, 138 many of them are clustered in three regions displaying extensive diversification, corresponding to the N-139 terminal region of the ORF1a polyprotein, the Spike protein, and the uncharacterized protein encoded 140 by ORF8 (Figure 1 and Figure S1 ). 141 142
body_text.section: Comparative genomics unveils fast-evolving regions of SARS-related CoV genomes 126

body_text.text: Among these three fast-evolving proteins, we focused on the ORF8 protein as it is one of the so-called 144 accessory proteins, which does not participate in viral replication (32, 33), raising the possibility that it 145 might have a role in viral pathogenesis. It is a predicted secreted protein present only in some Beta-146
body_text.section: Identification of novel immunoglobin protein families in CoVs 143

body_text.text: CoVs, including SARS-CoV-2 but not the MERS-like clade. Profile-profile comparisons using a sequence-147 profile built from the multiple sequence alignment of all available ORF8 proteins showed it to be 148 unexpectedly homologous to the membrane-anchored ORF7a protein from the same subset of Beta-149
body_text.section: Identification of novel immunoglobin protein families in CoVs 143

body_text.text: CoVs, and several proteins (variously annotated as ORF9 or ORF10) from a subset of bat Alpha-CoVs 150 The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.04.977736 doi: bioRxiv preprint terminal transmembrane (TM) helix and the acquisition of a long insert between stands 3 and 4 with a 159 conserved cysteine which might facilitate dimerization through disulfide-bond formation (Figure 2A) . 160
body_text.section: Identification of novel immunoglobin protein families in CoVs 143

body_text.text: The homology model of ORF8, based on the structure of SARS-CoV ORF7a (pdb id:1XAK), suggests that 161 this insert augments a potential peptide-ligand binding groove that has been proposed for ORF7a 162 ( Figure 2B and Figure S3 ). Hence, the emergence of the insert has gone hand-in-hand with the 163 acquisition of a modified interaction interface. 164 165 Besides these families, we identified a fourth family of Ig domains from the same Alpha-CoVs which 166 contain the above-discussed ORF7a/8-like Ig family ( Figure 3A ). These Alpha-CoVs typically possess one 167 or two paralogous copies annotated as either ORF4a/b or NS5a/b. From their sequences, these Ig 168 domains are not closely related to the ORF7a and ORF8 Ig domains ( Figure S4 ). However, profile-profile 169 searches have shown that they are related to Ig domains found in the adenoviral E3-CR1 proteins 170 (probability: 90% of matching the Pfam CR1 Ig domain profile) ( Figure S4 ). In these searches, they also 171 yield weaker hits to two other Ig domains, namely the poxviral decoy interferon receptors and human T-172 cell surface CD3 zeta ( Figure S4 ). 173
body_text.section: Identification of novel immunoglobin protein families in CoVs 143

body_text.text: Phylogenetic analysis of ORF7a, ORF8 and Alpha-CoV Ig domains shows that each group represents a 176 distinct clade ( Figure 2C ). The tree topology of ORF7a mirrors that of the polymerase tree ( Figure 3A) ; 177 however, the topology of the ORF8-Ig clade is not consistent with it. This might be due to a 178 recombination event between the SARS-related CoVs (as suggested by the similarity plot analysis) 179 and/or unusual divergence under selection. To better understand the functional difference between 180 ORF8 and ORF7a, we examined the column-wise Shannon entropy in the 20 amino acid alphabet and 181 found that the ORF8 has significantly higher mean entropy than ORF7a (ORF8: 1.09 vs ORF7a: 0.22, p< 182 10 -16 for the H0 of congruent means by t-test) ( Figure 2D
body_text.section: ORF8 is a fast-evolving protein in SARS-related CoVs 175

body_text.text: The presence of multiple Ig domains with different affinities in CoVs prompted us to more generally 215 survey animal viruses for Ig domains. By using the Pfam models (39) and our own PSSMs created from 216 PSI-BLAST runs with Ig domains (12), we were able to identify about 17 distinct viral Ig domain families 217 in a wider diversity of animal viruses ( Figure 3B and Table S2 ). In addition to CoVs, such Ig domain 218 proteins can be found in adenoviruses, NCLDVs, Herpesviruses and Phenuiviruses. These viral Ig domains 219 are highly divergent; many of them are only found in certain viral groups. However, the majority have an While ORF8 is a paralog of ORF7a, its lack of the TM segment, unique insert and significantly more rapid 247 evolution suggest that it has acquired a distinct function and has been under strong positive selection 248
body_text.section: Divergent Ig proteins with a comparable architecture are deployed by distinct viruses 214

body_text.text: One possible mechanism is that, like the adenoviral CR1 proteins, it interferes with MHC molecules to 249 attenuate antigen presentation, resulting in ineffective detection of the virus by the host immune 250 system. Consistent with this, the SARS-CoV ortholog translocates to the ER (48) and its higher variability 251 indicates probable selection due to its interaction with a rapidly evolving host molecule. Notably information about the genomes that were used in this study, refer to Table S1 . 285 286 . CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license author/funder. Each point represents a different slicing window size from the alignment with a different step size between each point. For each plot, the window size and step size are shown in the top left. Horizontal bars above the top plot correspond to the different open reading frames of the SARS-CoV-2 genome (NC_045512.2). Each different colored line corresponds to the nucleotide similarity between the human SARS-CoV-2 genome (NC_045512.2) and the respective SARS-related CoV genome. The red arrows and solid lines surround regions which display recombination within the SARS-related CoV genomes. The single red arrows point to specific regions of recombination.
body_text.section: Divergent Ig proteins with a comparable architecture are deployed by distinct viruses 214

FIGREF0.text: Figure 2A) (probability=94% of profile-profile match) (34). ORF7a is a known member of the 151 immunoglobulin (Ig) domain superfamily and is specifically related to extracellular metazoan Ig domains 152 that are involved in adhesion, such as ICAM (35, 36). The Beta-CoV ORF8, ORF7a and the Alpha-CoV Ig 153 domains display a classic β-sandwich fold with seven β-stands and share the characteristic pattern of 154 two cysteines which form stabilizing disulfide bonds with metazoan Ig domains(Figure 2AandFigure S2) 155 (37). However, they are unified as a clade by the presence of an additional pair of conserved disulfide-156 bonding cysteines(Figure 2A). Nonetheless, there are notable structural differences between the three 157 groups of proteins. ORF8 is distinguished from ORF7a and Alpha-CoV Ig proteins by the loss of the C

FIGREF1.text: ). By comparing column-wise entropies in both 183 the 20 amino acid and a reduced 8-letter alphabet (where amino acids are grouped based on similar 184 side-chain chemistry), we found at least 14 positions in ORF8 which show high entropy in both alphabets 185 as compared to a single position in ORF7a (Figure 2D). This indicates that ORF8 is a fast-evolving protein 186 under selection for diversity as contrast to ORF7a. Strikingly, one of these highly variable positions, 187 which features residues with very different side characters (hydrophobic, acidic, alcoholic and proline),188 corresponding to Leu84 was also identified as the most variable position across 54 closely related 189 human SARS-CoV-2 genome sequences (38). In our structural model, this residue is positioned at the 190 domain proteins are newly acquired in subsets of Alpha-and Beta-CoVs 196 We examined the distribution of CoV Ig proteins in the context of a phylogenetic tree of both Beta-and 197 Alpha-CoVs based on their polymerase proteins (Figure 3A). Other than the two subsets of Beta-CoVs 198 and Alpha-CoVs that contain the above-described Ig domain proteins, no other CoVs contain any Ig 199 domain proteins (Figure 3A). The immediate sister-groups of the Ig-containing CoVs typically have Spike, 200 E, M and N, and one or two other uncharacterized accessory proteins which are not Ig domains to our 201 best knowledge. The Alpha-CoV ORF9/10 share a C-terminal TM helix and, along with ORF7a of the Beta-202CoVs, lack the insert in the Ig domain (Figure 2A). Hence, it is possible that this architecture represents 203 the ancestral state which was present in the common ancestor of both Alpha-CoVs and Beta-CoVs. 204Under this scenario, the protein was displaced/lost both in certain Alpha-CoVs and Beta-CoVs. 205Alternatively, ORF7a could have been exchanged between Alpha-and Beta-CoVs by a recombination 206 event. In both scenarios, ORF8 arose likely via a duplication of ORF7a in specifically the Beta-CoVs. 207Although we couldn't identify the ultimate precursors of the CoV Ig domains, they are likely to have 208 been acquired on at least two independent occasions from different sources. The CoV ORF7a-ORF8 209 families might have derived from the metazoan adhesion Ig families, and the ORF4a/b-like Ig domains of 210 Alpha-CoVs were likely acquired from adenoviral CR1 Ig domains with which they share some

FIGREF2.text: 220 architecture comparable to the CoV-Ig domains, with an N-terminal signal peptide, one or multiple Ig 221 domains and a C-terminal TM region often followed by a stretch of basic residues. Thus, although the Ig 222 domains are not the universally preserved component of viruses, they have been acquired and selected 223 independently by a wide range of viruses. The presence of a proofreading 3'-5' exonuclease has been 224 proposed to favor the emergence of larger RNA genomes in CoVs (40). Indeed, this might have also 225 contributed to the acquisition of potential pathogenesis factors such as the Ig domains described herein 226 which are comparable to those seen in DNA viruses. 227 228 Novel CoV Ig domain proteins are potential immune modulators 229 Why have diverse viruses independently acquired the Ig domain during their evolution? First, the Ig 230 domains are major mediators of adhesive interactions in both eukaryotes and prokaryotes (37, 41, 42). 231 Thus, this domain can be used for adherence for cell to cell spread (e.g. herpesviral Ig domain proteins) 232 (43). Further, Ig domains are major building blocks of metazoan immune systems. Thus, viruses often 233 utlize this domain to disrupt immune signaling of the host. For example, in adenoviruses, the CR1 Ig 234 domain proteins have been shown to block the surface expression on infected cells of class I major 235 histocompatibility complex molecules by blocking their trafficking from the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) 236 to Golgi (44). This has been shown to affect the host inflammatory response and modulates the 237 presentation of viral antigens to T-cells (45). In poxvirus, the secreted Ig domain proteins function as 238 interferon receptors or decoys that bind the interferon-α/β and disrupt signaling via the endogenous 239 host receptors (46). Further, SARS-ORF7a has been implicated in the interaction with bone marrow 240 stromal antigen 2 (BST-2), which tethers budding virions to the host cell in a broad-spectrum antiviral 241 response, to prevent the N-linked glycosylation of BST-2 thereby crippling the host response against the 242 virus (47). Given their shared evolutionary history and similar sequence and structural features, we 243 predict that the newly identified CoV Ig domain proteins, such as ORF8 of SARS-CoV-2, might similarly 244 function as immune modulators. 245 246

FIGREF3.text: -CoV ORF8 isolates from civets and early stages of the human epidemic are intact, it split up 253 into two ORFs (ORF8a and ORF8b) during the subsequent human epidemic (49). , the presence of fast-evolving ORF8 Ig domain proteins in the SARS-related viruses, 259 including the emergent 2019 SARS-CoV-2, suggests that they might be potential pathogenicity factors 260 which counter or attenuate the host immune response and might have facilitated the transmission 261 between hosts. We hope that the discovery and analyses of the novel Ig domain proteins reported here 262 will help the community better understand the evolution and pathogenesis mechanisms of Genome comparison analysis of SARS-related CoVs. 276 Similarity plot of SARS-related CoVs against human SARS-CoV-2 Wuhan-Hu-1 genome (NC_045512.2), 277 based on a multiple sequence alignment of the whole genomes. FIGREF4.text: Sequence, structure and evolutionary analysis of novel Ig domain proteins in SARSlike Ig domain families. Each sequence in the MSA was labelled by its species abbreviation 290 followed by its source. The predicted secondary structure is shown above each alignment and the 291 consensus is shown below the super-alignment, where h stands for hydrophobic residues, s for small 292 residues, and p for polar residues. Two pairs of conserved cysteines that form disulfide bonds are 293highlighted in red. (B) Homology model of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8-Ig domain (YP_009724396.1) and the 294 location of the hypervariable position corresponding to Leu84 in the predicted ligand-binding groove. 295 The β-sheets of the common core of the Ig fold are colored in blue, the insert in ORF8-Ig in orange and 296 the loops in grey. The characteristic disulfide bonds are highlighted in yellow. (C) Maximum likelihood 297 phylogenetic analysis of CoV Ig domain families. Support values out of 100 bootstraps are shown for the 298 major branches only. (D) Entropy plot for the ORF7a and ORF8 proteins in betacoronavirus. Left: 299 Shannon entropy computed for each column for a character space of 20 amino acids and presented as 300 mean entropy in a sliding window of 30 residues. The mean entropy across the entire length of the 301 protein is indicated as a green horizontal line. Right: Shannon entropy in regular amino acid alphabet (20 302 amino acids) are shown above the zero line in shades of orange. Shannon entropy in a reduced alphabet 303 of 8 residues are shown below the zero line in shades of blue. If a position shows high entropy in both 304 alphabets it is a sign of potential positive selection at those positions for amino acids of

FIGREF5.text: (A) Genomic structure analysis of SARS-related CoVs. The tree of coronavirus was built based 309 on an MSA of a coronavirus RNA-directed, RNA polymerase domain using a maximum likelihood model. 310 Supporting values from 100 bootstraps are shown for the major branches only. The genome structure of 311 major representative CoVs are shown right to the terminal clade of the phylogenetic tree. (B) 312 Representative domain architectures of the Ig components in different animal viruses. Proteins were 313 grouped based on their families, except for proteins of coronavirus, which were grouped based on their 314 genus. For the information of the NCBI accession numbers, refer to the supplementary data. Genome comparison analysis of SARS-related CoVs.

The transmembrane regions 80 were predicted by the TMHMM Server v. 2.0 (20). 81Identification of distinct viral Ig domain proteins 83By using the protein remote relationship detection methods, we generated a collection of distinct Ig 84 domains from the Pfam database (21) and also from our local domain database. Then, we utilized the 85 hmmscan program of the HMMER package (22) and RPS-BLAST (12, 23) to retrieve the homologs from 86The evolutionary history was inferred by using the Maximum Likelihood method based on the JTT 90 w/freq. model (24). The tree with the highest log likelihood is shown. Support values out of 100 91 bootstraps are shown next to the branches (25). Initial tree(s) for the heuristic search were obtained 92 automatically by applying Neighbor-Join and BioNJ algorithms to a matrix of pairwise distances 93 estimated using a JTT model, and then selecting the topology with the superior log likelihood value. A 94 discrete Gamma distribution was used to model evolutionary rate differences among sites (4 95 categories). The rate variation model allowed for some sites to be evolutionarily invariable. The tree is 96 drawn to scale, with branch lengths measured in the number of substitutions per site. The tree diagram 97 was generated using MEGA Tree Explorer (26) 98Position-wise Shannon entropy (H) for a given multiple sequence alignment was calculated using the 101
